awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Aquaculture: Education for Underserved Alaskan Communities to Promote Workforce Development in Fisheries Industries
awd_abstract_narration:
This project builds on the University of Alaska Fisheries, Seafood, and Maritime Initiative to develop a strong and sustainable workforce particularly in Alaska's coastal communities. A Gap Analysis performed for the Initiative identified the following as needs for Alaskan fisheries industries: 1) grow career awareness; 2) develop career pathways; 3) improve access to employment; 4) educate Alaskans for fisheries, seafood, and maritime employment; and 5) improve industry engagement and accountability. This project will develop a semester intensive program to increase the labor pool available for aquaculture facilities, while supporting student employment opportunities following a short educational intervention. This model of offering short, intensive programs that support gains in knowledge and relevant skills may apply to other aspects of the Fisheries Technology program, such as fisheries management, as well as other university programs that educate technicians. All seven of the aquaculture associations in Alaska, accounting for 25 hatcheries, have offered space, time, and mentorship to support this proposal. This inclusive collaboration for technician training in aquaculture is unprecedented in Alaska.

The University of Alaska Southeast Fisheries Technology program will offer a hands-on, semester-intensive program for entry level aquaculture/hatchery technicians. During this semester-long program, students will take 12 industry endorsed university credits over a four-month period that will give them the knowledge and skills needed to start work in the fisheries industry. This semester-intensive program was designed in response to a needs assessment completed by members from 16 hatchery organizations, which defined the need for hands-on, short-duration education programs in basic aquaculture education. This program will include basic aquaculture techniques used in Alaska salmon hatcheries, hatchery design and function, species biology, production processes, skiff operation, and outboard engine troubleshooting. The program will be based out of Sitka, Alaska, which is the headquarters of a regional Aquaculture Association, three unique hatcheries, and the University of Alaska Sitka campus. Students will complete an internship during the semester, to reinforce what they have learned, and will visit at least two other facilities around the state, thus exposing them to a variety of operations and explore life at remote sites. Graduates from this program will have a solid knowledge base and skill set that many salmon enhancement sectors need for entry-level technicians and will gain the experience working alongside professionals in the industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Alaska Southeast Juneau Campus

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Alaska Southeast Sitka Campus

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The  Enhancing Aquaculture: (Education for Underserved Alaskan Communities to Promote Workforce Development in Fisheries Industries) project focused on trying to increase the number and diversity of Alaskans working in the aquaculture industry. The goal of this project was to do so by working hand-in-hand with Alaska?s numerous aquaculture associations, and ultimately for the Applied Fisheries Program at the University of Alaska Southeast (UAS) to be seen as a leader in salmon enhancement and aquaculture education throughout Alaska. 

 

Despite the numerous challenges of an Alaska budget and educational funding crisis (2019) and the COVID-19 global pandemic (2020), the project was able to shift toward enhancing it?s online delivery of aquaculture classes which not only helped in creating great courses, but also helped increase awareness and participation in these classes, especially amongst high school students.

 

One of the key elements of this project was the development of a hands-on aquaculture training program focused on Alaskan aquaculture. In the Fall of 2021, After postponing for two years due to COVID-19, a very successful cohort of students participated in the first, Alaskan Aquaculture Semester, a non-traditional semester intensive suite of classes focused on hands-on training and connecting students and employers all throughout the Alaskan aquaculture industry. This program relied heavily on industry participation, using their facilities as teaching laboratories, having their staff demonstrate skills and techniques, and having students placed in industry facilities through internships. The non-traditional, semester intensive format that engages students and connects them directly to employers is unique in teaching and education. We believe this to be a highly engaging educational format that, with strong ties to industry, could be successful in a number of other academic programs and industries. This program was highly successful and will be continued every fall semester moving forward. 

The education students receive through this project is not only giving them a career, but also the opportunity of a lifestyle. ?Working in Aquaculture facilities is challenging but incredibly rewarding. You get to live and play in the most beautiful places in the world all while working with really incredible species', that will amaze you at every stage of their life.?

The work that was done through this project and by the Applied Fisheries Program and faculty at UAS has clearly positioned them as a leader in aquaculture, mariculture, and salmon enhancement education throughout Alaska and the Pacific Northwest. This is clear not only from student success, but also from a $2 million dollar State of Alaska infrastructure investment into the UAS Applied Fisheries program and an additional $49 million dollars in federal support being brought to Alaska through the Alaska Mariculture Cluster, of which the UAS Applied Fisheries Program is a key partner. These investments and continued leadership in Alaskan aquaculture education from the UAS Applied Fisheries Program will vastly enhance these industries and meet the workforce needs of this growing and important sector.


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Joel Markis

Images (1 of )
  • Faculty and students in UAS's Applied Fisheries Program harvest sugar kelp (Saccharina latissima) grown as part of an aquaculture education program in Sitka Sound, Alaska
    Sara Ebersole
    Creative Commons
    Joel Markis
    Sugar Kelp Harvest
  • Faculty and students in UAS's Applied Fisheries Program inspect Coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) for health and condition. Fish are being reared as part of salmon enhancement aquaculture efforts in Sitka, Alaska
    Sara Ebersole
    Creative Commons
    Joel Markis
    Coho Inspection
  • A student in UAS's Applied Fisheries Program dissects a Coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) to examine its internal anatomy and look for signs of infection or disease as part of a fish pathology class.
    Sara Ebersole
    Creative Commons
    Joel Markis
    Coho Salmon Pathology Disection
  • Students in UAS's Applied Fisheries Program spawn Pink Salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) which will be incubated and reared for one year before being released as part of salmon enhancement aquaculture efforts in Sitka, Alaska
    Anna Laffrey
    Creative Commons
    Joel Markis
    Pink Salmon Spawning
  • A student in UAS's Applied Fisheries Program showcases a basket of Pacific Oysters (Crassostrea gigas) which are being sorted and graded prior to sale.
    Anna Laffrey
    Creative Commons
    Joel Markis
    Pacific Oyster Sorting
